channel.title: It's Pretty OK
channel.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
channel.description:
Why don’t more bars serve beer in pitchers? How do you pick a song for karaoke? What does the word “home” mean to you?
Those questions range from silly to serious, but if you’ve ever pondered the answers to all three in a single day, you’re not alone. Pour yourself a cup of coffee, crack a 40, or anything in between, and join the gang here at It’s Pretty OK as we attempt to answer these questions and many more. We promise it won’t be boring.
channel.itunes:summary:
Why don’t more bars serve beer in pitchers? How do you pick a song for karaoke? What does the word “home” mean to you?
Those questions range from silly to serious, but if you’ve ever pondered the answers to all three in a single day, you’re not alone. Pour yourself a cup of coffee, crack a 40, or anything in between, and join the gang here at It’s Pretty OK as we attempt to answer these questions and many more. We promise it won’t be boring.

item.title: Ep. 345: Lackluster Video
item.description: Wait, did they say DVDs?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Wait, did they say DVDs?
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang is together to talk about collections of physical media — especially DVDs. Strap in!MUSIC: “Training Montage” – The Mountain Goats

item.title: Ep. 344: DRAFT TALK
item.description: The annual moment when you think “maybe this year will be different!”
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: The annual moment when you think “maybe this year will be different!”
item.itunes:summary: With Max off the board this week, the rest of the gang gets together to talk about why sports drafts — the NBA draft in particular — hold such a strong allure.MUSIC: “Silk Chiffon (feat. Phoebe Bridgers)” – MUNA

item.title: Ep. 343: FOURTHPOD
item.description: Whatever it is, let’s taco bout it
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Whatever it is, let’s taco bout it
item.itunes:summary: Whatever it is, let’s taco bout it

item.title: Ep. 342: Hot Tub Pod Machine
item.description: A conversation that’s been simmering for a while
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A conversation that’s been simmering for a while
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together to discuss hot tubs, which Sean derisively refers to at one point as “human broth” but which were a fairly significant part of Max’s search for a new place to live. I feel like that’s probably enough for you to know in order to decide whether or not this episode is for you — not unlike hot tubs themselves.MUSIC: “Always Rhyme” – Homeboy Sandman

item.title: Ep. 341: Choosy Cooks Choose...
item.description: What we cook when we cook at home
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What we cook when we cook at home
item.itunes:summary: Sean is gone this week for a reason that may or may not have something to do with Hard Mountain Dew, but that’s not going to stop the rest of the gang from convening to talk about cooking routines. What are the things that you make a point of only eating out at restaurants (or things that you only eat at home)? And can trying cooking some of those things at home ruin the special-ness of the restaurant occasion?MUSIC: “Easy On Your Own” – Alvvays

item.title: Ep. 340: Where Have All the Rivalries Gone?
item.description: What makes the bitterest feuds in sports so great?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What makes the bitterest feuds in sports so great?
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together to discuss whether the sports rivalry is still alive and well, particularly in professional sports in the U.S. How much of the seeming fade of these bitter rivalries is due to changing attitudes among new generations, and how much is dumb stuff like fantasy football and the ubiquity of legal sports gambling? And why do the greatest sports rivalries often have so little to do with sports themselves?MUSIC: “TV Will Always Make Me Cry” – Alien Boy

item.title: Ep. 339: BEDtv
item.description: To tube or not to tube, that is the question
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: To tube or not to tube, that is the question
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang talks about putting (or not putting) a TV in your bedroom. What goes into that momentous decision? Also, Sean gets irrationally angry about an audiobook he listened to, and as always, Pierce apologizes.MUSIC: “Hurricanes and Hand Grenades” – Jason Isbell

item.title: Ep. 338: College GamePod
item.description: Talking about all the pregame talking
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about all the pregame talking
item.itunes:summary: This week, the Sports Bois™ convene to talk about the phenomenon of pregame shows, particularly for football. Two important notes:1) This was recorded before College GameDay actually went to Boone, NC, which produced (among other things) this phenomenal intro video voiced by Wright Thompson.2) Thanks to frustrating Skype connection stuff, the crosstalk/awkward pause conundrum is worse than usual!MUSIC: “Let Us Die“ – King Princess

item.title: Ep. 337: An Honest LIV-ing
item.description: Talking sportswashing and whatnot
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking sportswashing and whatnot
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together to talk about the ways that the sports industry is changing, especially the introduction of Saudi oil money in the form of the new LIV Golf tour. And we get the most harrowing edition of “Pierce Is Sorry” yet.MUSIC: “9 to 5” – Dolly Parton

item.title: Ep. 336: Sight Unseen
item.description: Dealing with moving when you can’t see the place in person
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Dealing with moving when you can’t see the place in person
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together to talk about a phenomenon they’ve all experienced in the last two years: the remote house tour.MUSIC: “Hangover Song” – MJ Lenderman

item.title: Ep. 335: Still Tippin'
item.description: Paying a little extra
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Paying a little extra
item.itunes:summary: Because everything is cyclical, this week, the gang is talking about tipping. The pandemic has changed our relationship with the practice, and it’s time to discuss it again — especially now that more places are starting to phase tipping out in favor of added service fees and the like.MUSIC: “Exhibit C“ – Jay Electronica

item.title: Ep. 334: The One About Home Workspaces
item.description: Where we work when we don’t work from work
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Where we work when we don’t work from work
item.itunes:summary: This week, Max, Pierce and Sean talk about the act of cultivating a home workspace — something so many of us have had to do in the last two years — and some of the ways that that process can maybe go wrong. Does Sean figure out in real time that he ought to rearrange a couple things in his apartment? Maybe!MUSIC: “Gimmie Shelter” – Merry Clayton

item.title: Ep. 333: Three White Guys in Their 30s Talking About F1
item.description: Something new and different
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Something new and different
item.itunes:summary: You’ve never heard that before, right? Apologies if the audio is glitchier than usual.MUSIC: “Kawasaki Backflip” – Dogleg

item.title: Ep. 332: The Overcooked Pork Support Group
item.description: What food do YOU remember from your childhood (but maybe not in a good way)?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What food do YOU remember from your childhood (but maybe not in a good way)?
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together to talk about the foods that they ate frequently in their youth that they’ve had to grapple with as they’ve gotten older and started cooking for themselves. Spaghetti comes up a few times, as do the low-fat craze of the late ’80s and early ’90s and the fear of trichinosis that led every parent for multiple generations to cook pork way too long.MUSIC: “(I’m) Screwed” – Titus Andronicus

item.title: Ep. 331: Going, Going, Juan
item.description: It’s Juan-Soto-trade emergency podcast time, y’all
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: It’s Juan-Soto-trade emergency podcast time, y’all
item.itunes:summary: This week, the It’s Pretty OK Sports Brain Trust™️ convenes to talk about the Juan Soto situation. He’s turned down a contract from the Nationals that looks huge on paper but is not nearly as good as it might appear, and now the team is expected to trade him. Where does that leave Pierce, who has been clinging to his Nats fandom even after leaving the D.C. area, specifically because of Soto?MUSIC: “Worth It” – beabadoobee

item.title: Ep. 330: A Return to Rulemaking
item.description: Bringing back a classic It’s Pretty OK format
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Bringing back a classic It’s Pretty OK format
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang is back together for the first time in several weeks. What better way to celebrate than by revisiting a classic pod concept and seeing if we can’t make a rule for society to live by? This time, it’s about what is acceptable attire for a craft brewery — specifically, is it okay to wear another brewery’s T-shirt?MUSIC: “Gotta Let It Go” – Joyce Manor

item.title: Ep. 329: Los Angeles Is Part of the Midwest Now, Apparently
item.description: The B1G gets even B1G-ger
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: The B1G gets even B1G-ger
item.itunes:summary: This week, Sean and Pierce talk conference realignment. Heads spin as they attempt to understand the concept of a college athletic conference that stretches from Piscataway, New Jersey to Los Angeles.MUSIC: “Elvis Is in the Freezer” – Ratboys

item.title: Ep. 328: Borrowed Nostalgia
item.description: On Stranger Things and “remembering” things you weren’t even alive for
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On Stranger Things and “remembering” things you weren’t even alive for
item.itunes:summary: This week, it’s just Sean and Pierce, and they’re talking about Stranger Things and the phenomenon of borrowed nostalgia. What’s different about this show as opposed to other prestige-TV period pieces like Mad Men or The Americans? And why doesn’t Sean like the Kate Bush song as much as everyone else?NOTE: This episode was recorded before the release of the Stranger Things season 4 finale release, but after we had watched the previous S4 episodes. There’s not much in the way of spoiler-type stuff, but keep that in mind — if you’ve been saving Season 4 to watch until you could binge the whole thing, maybe wait until you’re done to listen?MUSIC: “Once More for the Ocean” – Slothrust

item.title: Ep. 327: That's What Makes U Beautiful
item.description: A chat about pretty campuses
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A chat about pretty campuses
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together to discuss what makes a college campus beautiful. Is it more than just having a picturesque quad and a few buildings designed in an aesthetically pleasing style of classical architecture? (Yes.) Pierce finally says something nice about Virginia Tech; how long will it be before he goes back to reflexively insulting them? (It’ll be less than a minute.) And we have perhaps our most thrilling Rolling Stone rock trivia question yet.MUSIC: “Mulholland Dr.” – Bartees Strange

item.title: Ep. 326: It's McPodcast Season Again
item.description: On challenge burgers and other over-the-top menu items
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On challenge burgers and other over-the-top menu items
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang is talking about “stunt foods" — the parade of food challenges (like the Steak ‘n Shake 7x7) and ridiculous seasonal items (like Burger King’s black-bunned Halloween burger) that fast food customers find themselves bombarded with. Is this all the fault of Hardee’s and their risqué mid-2000s burger commercials? And will Sean take more stances that are probably more anticapitalist than he intended for them to be?MUSIC: “The Amarillo Kid” – Craig Finn

item.title: Ep. 325: Summer Treats Make Me Feel Fine
item.description: When the weather is hot, the sweet treats come out!
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: When the weather is hot, the sweet treats come out!
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together to talk about the frozen delicacies that have sustained them through many a hot summer. Will Sean get overly regionally proud about the snowball and then rebut an argument about snowcones that no one actually made? You better believe it. Do multiple people on this podcast endorse the consumption of custard on scorching summer days? Incredibly, yes! And will Max be shocked to discover that the thing he thought was a Northeastern specialty is all over the place, just without the region-specific name? You’ll have to listen to find out.MUSIC: “She Bangs the Drums” – The Stone Roses

item.title: A Special Advance Screening of Ep. 324!
item.description: On being the first one in the theater
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On being the first one in the theater
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang is talking about the fact that Max went to a midnight movie premiere (no matter what time zone he saw it in). They discuss the phenomenon of the special early release of movies/books/video games/etc. before the conversation unexpectedly turns into a referendum on Kevin’s approach to capitalism. You know, normal stuff.MUSIC: “Heavy Heart” – Bartees Strange

item.title: Ep. 323: Let Them Email About Cake
item.description: On corporate birthday wishes and exploding inboxes
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On corporate birthday wishes and exploding inboxes
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together to talk about the fact that Pierce is still getting email updates from local businesses in a town he hasn’t lived in in nearly two full years. How has everyone’s inbox gone so crazy? Can Pierce convince us that he’s actually in the right somehow? And is Max ever going to check his damn email?MUSIC: “Intervention” – A Giant Dog

item.title: Ep. 322: Trust the Pod-Cess
item.description: Death, taxes, and Daryl Morey’s project falling short yet again
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Death, taxes, and Daryl Morey’s project falling short yet again
item.itunes:summary: This week, the Sports Bois™️ are together to talk about yet another NBA conference finals that finds itself without Joel Embiid and the Philadelphia 76ers. And while Sean would probably like to spend the entire pod taking a victory lap about that, it fortunately turns into a broader discussion about the dangers of sports teams taking an entirely long-term (or short-term, for that matter) approach.MUSIC: “I Don’t Live Here Anymore (feat. Lucius) – The War on Drugs

item.title: Ep. 321: I Pod, You Pod, We All Pod About iPods
item.description: A send-off to the device that changed music
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A send-off to the device that changed music
item.itunes:summary: This week, Sean talks to Pierce and Max about “the end of the iPod” and what it means. He also reveals that he is, in the year of our lord two thousand and twenty-two, the owner of a still-thriving (modified) iPod and tries to explain why he is the perfect target audience for the iPod modding craze.MUSIC: “Chaise Longue” – Wet LegADDITIONAL MATERIALAn Ode to the iPod Classic (The Ringer)iPod Modders Give Apple’s Abandoned Music Player New Life (WIRED)

item.title: Ep. 320: To Recommend or Not to Recommend
item.description: Is it really better to give than to receive?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Is it really better to give than to receive?
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together to discuss recommendations. Is it better to get a good recommendation or to give one? Does the decision change if it’s not about a good recommendation, but just any recommendation? And why are we all so self-centered? Plus, a Pierce apology and a trivia question about unlikely high school classmates.MUSIC: “Detective Lieutenant” – Drug Church

item.title: Ep. 319: The Great Revisitation
item.description: A look back at the movies we used to love
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A look back at the movies we used to love
item.itunes:summary: This week, Sean is back and the full gang is talking about revisiting movies that you used to watch when you were a kid. Just how goofy is the Ewok storyline from Return of the Jedi? Was his portrayal of the Scorpion King really what catapulted Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson towards becoming the biggest movie star in the world? And is the fact that Flubber is only about 90 minutes long enough to offset the fact that it’s, well, Flubber?MUSIC“Without Me” – EminemADDITIONAL MATERIALSean on the On the Record with Ambi podcast (Apple Podcasts)Big Thief performs “Simulation Swarm” on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert (YouTube)

item.title: Ep. 318: Pod-triot's Day
item.description: Town gatherings galore
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Town gatherings galore
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang gets together (minus Sean) to talk about local celebrations. Not so much the big things that gain a national reputation like Mardi Gras or the cherry blossom festival in DC — more like your small-town strawberry fests and whatnot. Plus, as always, Pierce apologizes, and we have a rock trivia question.MUSIC: ”Now & Later Gators” – Freddie Gibbs, Curren$y and the Alchemist

item.title: Ep. 317: (Company) Swag Surfin'
item.description: Talking about those co-branded Patagonia vests
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about those co-branded Patagonia vests
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang convenes to talk about the various perks that are afforded to the modern knowledge worker by their employer — especially all the branded jackets and backpacks and such. How should we feel about being made walking billboards for our companies? And what happens when we don’t work there anymore?Somewhat predictably, Sean lashes out at corporate America, although it may just be because he’s not getting any swag at work. And there’s a Mad Men reference…but it’s not from Pierce for once.MUSIC: “Country” – Good MorningADDITIONAL MATERIAL: What ‘Severance’ Gets Right About Infantilizing Office Perks (The New York Times)

item.title: Ep. 316: WePodded
item.description: Talking about the flood of “CE-shOws”
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about the flood of “CE-shOws”
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang talks about the flood of entertainment content based around problematic tech CEOs like Travis Kalanick (Uber), Elizabeth Holmes (Theranos), and Adam Neumann (WeWork). Why are there so many books, shows, podcasts, podcasts based on books, shows based on podcasts, etc. about these people?MUSIC: “Halfway Out the Door” – Romero

item.title: Ep. 315: The One About Awards Shows
item.description: Who’s still watching them in 2022?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Who’s still watching them in 2022?
item.itunes:summary: This week, it’s just Sean and Pierce, and they’re trying to talk about the Academy Awards — and awards shows in general — while desperately avoiding any discussion of the only part of the Oscars that anyone really seems to be talking about. Did it work? Hard to say.MUSIC: “Change Your Mind” – BAD MOVES

item.title: Ep. 314: Live from the 919
item.description: Talkin’ bout tasty beverages, y’all
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talkin’ bout tasty beverages, y’all
item.itunes:summary: Unfortunately, the initial version of Episode 314 was lost to a technical issue. But in exchange for waiting it out for a week, you get an extra special version of the pod recorded LIVE from the triumphant return of the It’s Pretty OK “Corporate Retreat”/NCAA Tournament Trip!After a night of drinking many — and we do mean many — tiki drinks in Raleigh, first-time/long-time Robert joins the gang to discuss cocktails and whether or not they should be a little bit disgusting.MUSIC: “Phantoms (feat. Open Mike Eagle and Kendra Morris)” – Czarface & MF DOOM

item.title: Ep. 313: The Coach K Farewell Tour Special
item.description: On long goodbyes that maybe last a little too long?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: On long goodbyes that maybe last a little too long?
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang is talking about what has certainly felt like the most hyped sporting event of our lifetimes: Duke basketball coach Mike Krzyzewski’s final regular-season game against North Carolina. Are they talking about the game itself? Of course not. They explore why it feels so weird to have farewell tours for coaches — or for any individuals in team sports, for that matter — and how this is probably all ESPN’s fault.MUSIC: “Stuck” – Oceanator

item.title: Ep. 312: Poddle
item.description: Talking about the latest gaming craze
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about the latest gaming craze
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang is talking about Wordle and other games that don’t let you do infinite play. Does it turn into a minor squabble over Wordle “hard mode”? Sure does. Does it then segue into a grim look at the future of the ever-consolidating entertainment industry? You better believe it!MUSIC: “The Hardest Cut” – Spoon

item.title: Ep. 311: Feeding the Content Beast
item.description: Talking about the Great Netflix Explosion™️
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about the Great Netflix Explosion™️
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang is talking about Netflix and the explosion of approximately 8 billion new shows of varying quality, seemingly tuned to every possible combination of micro-interests. What’s the deal with that? And why does Sean hate the word “content” so much?MUSIC: “Amber” – 311

item.title: Ep. 310: Dem Franchise Boyz PART 2!
item.description: Evaluating a new generation of NBA superstars
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Evaluating a new generation of NBA superstars
item.itunes:summary: This week, Sean, Pierce and Kevin revisit a conversation they had way back in November 2016 about which NBA star you’d want to build a franchise around. They’re pretty sure they all got it wrong (some more hilariously than others), so they try to assess who were the actual right answers back in 2016 — and then run it back to draft from a new generation of superstars.MUSIC: “Nuthin' But a 'G' Thang” – Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg

item.title: Ep. 309: It's a Matter of Perspection
item.description: Talking about the way we watch sports, y’all
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Talking about the way we watch sports, y’all
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang is all together to talk about the way that we watch sports. Specifically, is the way that live sports are filmed for TV broadcast wrong? And what the hell does any of that have to do with cows? MUSIC: “Gallo Pinto” – Daniela Andrade

item.title: Ep. 308: Hi, I'm Johnny Knoxville, Welcome to the Podcast
item.description: Is there anything funnier than someone getting hit in the face?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Is there anything funnier than someone getting hit in the face?
item.itunes:summary: This week, Sean is back after missing last pod due to COVID, and he can’t stop talking about the fact that there’s a new Jackass movie coming out — so the gang talks about nostalgia for a certain kind of comedy that doesn’t get made all that often anymore.MUSIC: “Be That Man” – Madeline Kenney

item.title: Ep. 307: Members, Only?
item.description: Should you join the club? Maybe!
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Should you join the club? Maybe!
item.itunes:summary: This week, Sean is on the injured list with a condition that may or may not rhyme with SHMOVID-19, so the rest of the gang steps in to have a discussion about membership programs. No, not like Costco (although Costco is mentioned) — more like brewery/winery memberships or season passes at ski mountains. They talk about how these programs can help you connect with a new community and revisit how dumb it was for Pierce and Kevin to get Wizards season tickets way back when.MUSIC: “Be a Part” – Dinosaur Jr.

item.title: Ep. 306: Calling an Audible
item.description: They’re like books, but for your earballs
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: They’re like books, but for your earballs
item.itunes:summary: This week, Sean, Max and Pierce talk about audiobooks — a thing they’ve definitely never done before. Sean’s been revising his stance on them. He even made a ham-fisted attempt at defining some audiobook rules for himself…and then broke them almost immediately. But maybe it was a good thing that he did? Plus, another riveting installment of Rolling Stone Rock Trivia Calendar Trivia™️.MUSIC: “Bunny Is A Rider” – Caroline Polachek

item.title: Ep. 305: SPORTS POD GO DAWGS
item.description: All hail Stetson Bennett, the future Chevy King of South Georgia
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: All hail Stetson Bennett, the future Chevy King of South Georgia
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang does an honest to god sports pod: they’re talking about the national championship game won by Georgia. Is Georgia defensive tackle Jordan Davis the largest man who has ever lived? (Maybe!) Remember when Brent Musburger was super horny on national television that time? (Hell yes, I do!) And will Sean stop trying to turn this into a rant about Chargers coach Brandon Staley calling that timeout? (Honestly, probably not!)MUSIC: “Up from Below” – Remember Sports

item.title: Ep. 304: Peyton Manning, Shailene Woodley and Aaron Rodgers Walk Into a Bar
item.description: Who’s a celebrity, and who’s just famous?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Who’s a celebrity, and who’s just famous?
item.itunes:summary: It’s 2022, and the gang is back to its routine of probing the depths of Pierce’s brain on a weekly basis. This time, they’re talking about the nature of celebrity — especially as it relates to athletes. If you stick around for a few minutes, you’ll get to hear Sean uncork what may be a pretty silly opinion about the relative fame of Aaron Rodgers and Shailene Woodley.MUSIC: “Going Down the Road Feelin’ Bad” – Lucinda Williams & Friends

item.title: Ep. 303: A (Holiday) Tradition Very Much Like Many Others
item.description: Who’s carving the roast beast this year?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Who’s carving the roast beast this year?
item.itunes:summary: Happy holidays, y’all! This week, the gang talks about what happens when it’s time to pass the responsibility for upholding existing traditions on to new faces/generations/etc., or to develop new traditions altogether. Christmas lasagna, anyone?MUSIC: “Back Door Santa” – Clarence CarterADDITIONAL MATERIALMeet the Investigators podcast: Pandora Papers special edition (ICIJ)The World of Five-Star (Apple Podcasts)

item.title: Ep. 302: You're Talking About Playoffs?
item.description: Is the postseason…basically just the season now?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Is the postseason…basically just the season now?
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang talks about the expanded seven-team playoff setup that the NFL is moving to this year. How does it compare to the NBA play-in tournament? Are they just asking for more players to get hurt or catch COVID-19? And most importantly, what basketball player is Nicolas Cage most like?MUSIC: “Love and Communication” – Cat Power

item.title: Ep. 301: Ugly Christmas Sweater Podcast
item.description: Why are fast-food joints selling you holiday clothing?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Why are fast-food joints selling you holiday clothing?
item.itunes:summary: This week, the gang is talking about “ugly Christmas sweaters.” Where did this phenomenon come from, and how the hell did it get hijacked by Popeye’s?MUSIC: “Hurt A Fly” – Squirrel Flower

item.title: Ep. 300: Are You Mad, Max?
item.description: Another classic It’s Pretty OK watch-along
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Another classic It’s Pretty OK watch-along
item.itunes:summary: This week, it’s the 300th episode of It’s Pretty OK. We did an episode about 40s for Episode 40 and online dating specials for Episodes 100 and 201, so it’s only natural that the gang would do another special thing for this major milestone. item.title: Ep. 161: I'm Not Growing Up, I'm Just Burning Out
item.description: Three millennials on the exhaustion millennials face every day
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Three millennials on the exhaustion millennials face every day
item.itunes:summary: You’ve maybe seen articles about millennial burnout in the New York Times or on BuzzFeed. The job market is still often brutal to navigate for young people, combined with rapidly-inflating costs of living and not-so-rapidly-inflating wages. And through all of it, there’s a chorus of Elon Musks and Gary Vaynerchuks shouting about “hustling,” “grinding,” and how if you’re not working 100 hours a week, you’re a failure. But there are skeptics out there who chalk it up to their favorite boogeyman—the coddled, entitled millennial who isn’t willing to “pay their dues” or “put in the work.” This week, Sean, Pierce, and Max talk about it all: burnout, the culture of “side hustles,” self-care, and why it’s sometimes good to just park yourself on the couch and watch TV or take a nap. MUSIC: “Burnout” - Green Day

item.title: Ep. 155: The Case for Dynasties?
item.description: Why teams that dominate their sports for a long time might not be so bad
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Why teams that dominate their sports for a long time might not be so bad
item.itunes:summary: Last night, No. 2 Clemson took a big lead early and never let up, cruising to a dominant 44-16 national championship win over No. 1 Alabama behind three passing touchdowns from true freshman Trevor Lawrence (two to wideout Justyn Ross) and three scores from tailback Travis Etienne. It was the fourth year in a row that the two squads met in the College Football Playoff, and the third in that span where the title was on the line, so leading up to the game, there was a tremendous backlash from fans and media calling the predictable championship matchup boring and bad for the sport. But is there actually an argument that dynastic teams dominating their respective sports is actually a good thing? Sean certainly thinks so. MUSIC: “Holding Out” - Metric

item.title: Ep. 152: Shady Bounce
item.description: Let’s talk about leaving the party without talking to anyone
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Let’s talk about leaving the party without talking to anyone
item.itunes:summary: It’s Christmas party season, which means it’s time to remind you that you should probably be leaving parties (especially work ones) early. It’s also time to discuss a gesture that has as many names as there are lazy ethnic stereotypes about European nationalities. You might know it as the Irish goodbye, the French exit, or maybe something else. Why do people leave social gatherings without saying goodbye? And are they…right to do so? MUSIC: “Back Door Santa” - Clarence Carter ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: Sean’s Christmas playlist (Spotify)

item.title: Ep. 151: Rank It Up
item.description: It’s year-end list time, y’all
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: It’s year-end list time, y’all
item.itunes:summary: The year-end rankings list: Is it the definitive guide to what mattered in culture this past year? Or is it just an exercise in the perpetual need to crank out more and more content faster and faster? And why are they released so long before the year actually ends? That’s what Sean, Pierce, and Max are discussing this week. MUSIC: “Love It If We Made It” - The 1975

item.title: Ep. 150: No More Cars?
item.description: What to make of Ford and GM focusing more on trucks and SUVs
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What to make of Ford and GM focusing more on trucks and SUVs
item.itunes:summary: Ford and GM are both significantly scaling back development and production of cars—not as in automobiles generally, but specifically non-truck/SUV vehicles. Sean, Pierce, and Max talk about what’s driving that change (no pun intended) and who is still buying American-made sedans. MUSIC: “Velvet Elvis” - Kacey Musgraves

item.title: Ep. 149: The Leftovers
item.description: So you left Thanksgiving with a bunch of tasty food for later. Now what?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: So you left Thanksgiving with a bunch of tasty food for later. Now what?
item.itunes:summary: Are you still enjoying your Thanksgiving leftovers? Pierce (who is) and Sean (who is not) talk this week about what to do with the post-Turkey Day turkey. Is microwaving your leftover mashed potatoes disrespectful to your parents/grandparents/aunts/friends/yourself? And if you must nuke, is there a way to nuke that keeps your food from drying out? As always, Pierce apologizes, and Sean gets emotional over books. MUSIC: “Near to the Wild Heart of Life” - Japandroids

item.title: Ep. 148: Check, Mate
item.description: A thrilling look at a thrilling event
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A thrilling look at a thrilling event
item.itunes:summary: Kevin joins Max and Pierce this week to discuss the greatest event in sport. No, not the Rams’ thrilling 54-51 win over the Chiefs on Monday Night Football. They’re talking, of course, about the 2018 World Chess Championship…which, as you listen to this, is still going on! MUSIC: “Soft Stud” - Black Belt Eagle Scout

item.title: Ep. 147: In This One, We Save the Food Network!
item.description: Okay, so maybe it doesn’t need saving. But can we make it better?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Okay, so maybe it doesn’t need saving. But can we make it better?
item.itunes:summary: We’re not saying the Food Network is dying, but maybe it’s in need of an injection of a little something new. We’re a little tired of watching a zillion Chopped reruns a day. Meanwhile, Vice is struggling with some high-profile talent departures, a string of sexual harassment allegations, and some significant financial woes. Does Pierce have an idea that weaves those things together? He sure does! MUSIC: “Everybody Wants to Be Famous” - Superorganism

item.title: Ep. 146: A Better Way to Cook
item.description: A discussion of the offerings out there for people looking to build confidence in the kitchen
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A discussion of the offerings out there for people looking to build confidence in the kitchen
item.itunes:summary: It’s Election Day, so the gang gives one last reminder of how important it is for you to go vote today. After that, they chat about meal-prep services like Blue Apron and Bon Appetit’s sub-site Basically, which recently launched 10x10, “a series of 10 simple, essential recipes that will make you a better cook.” Who are these offerings aimed at? How are they different? And, as always, the question we love to ask: Are they good? MUSIC: “Mistake” - Middle Kids ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: Welcome to Basically 10x10 (Bon Appetit)

item.title: Ep. 145: Little Pod of Horrors
item.description: What is it that makes us like having the pants scared off of us?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What is it that makes us like having the pants scared off of us?
item.itunes:summary: Tomorrow is Halloween, so the gang got together to talk about scary movies. Why do we like them so much? How have they evolved since the days of Freddy and Jason? And what happens when you watch them multiple times? MUSIC: “Quick” - Tank & the Bangas

item.title: Ep. 144: This Week's Theme...Is Theme Weeks
item.description: Our non-stop, wall-to-wall coverage of websites doing non-stop, wall-to-wall coverage of things
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Our non-stop, wall-to-wall coverage of websites doing non-stop, wall-to-wall coverage of things
item.itunes:summary: From Chocolate Chip Cookie Week (The Takeout) and Evil Week (Lifehacker) in the Gizmodo Media Group universe to Good Bad Movies Week and Patriots Week on The Ringer, the “____ Week” has become a major trope on millennial-focused websites, so the gang is talking about them this week. Where did they start? What is the purpose they serve? And are they any good? MUSIC: “Geyser” - Mitski

item.title: Ep. 143: Push It to the (Austin City) Limit

item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Sean returns from a trip to hear incredible music in the Nation of Texas
item.itunes:summary: About two years ago, the gang talked about festivals. For the first time since that episode, Sean went to a music festival—specifically, Austin City Limits. He talks to Pierce, Max, and Kevin about the bands he saw (many excellent ones), his appreciation of city-based festivals (explore the city in the morning, go to the festival in the afternoon), and whether his perspective on festivals has changed (you’ll have to listen to find out). MUSIC: “Maria También” - Khruangbin

item.title: Ep. 142: Where Legends Are Born
item.description: Is playoff baseball too “baseball-y?” (The answer is no.)
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Is playoff baseball too “baseball-y?” (The answer is no.)
item.itunes:summary: It’s October, which means it’s time for playoff baseball. Kevin joins Pierce and Sean to reminisce on their childhood relationships with baseball, how those relationships have changed, and whether it’s acceptable to have a 5-hour game. MUSIC: “Slow Rider” - Cuddle Magic

item.title: Ep. 141: Every Plastic Straw That's Ever Existed Still Exists
item.description: Some small steps that could help make a big difference
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Some small steps that could help make a big difference
item.itunes:summary: Max is still off with the kangaroos and the kookaburras, but Sean and Pierce got together to talk about the changes they’ve made to try to be more eco-conscious about food storage, etc. They talk about why reducing and reusing are every bit as important as recycling and share some small steps they’ve taken that might work for you too. Then Pierce apologizes, as always, and Sean shouts out a surprisingly timely movie he just saw for the first time. MUSIC: “Comfort Zone” - Partner

item.title: Ep. 140: You Don't Own This Podcast
item.description: Does anyone own anything anymore?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Does anyone own anything anymore?
item.itunes:summary: Kevin joins the pod this week, and the gang is talking about a person who found that a movie he purchased on iTunes had disappeared from his computer. Turns out he didn’t really buy it, he just “bought” it. Why is “buying” something digitally different from buying something physically? And more importantly, who stands to benefit from that difference? MUSIC: “Rock the Reaper” - Bat Fangs ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: You Don't Own the Music, Movies or Ebooks You 'Buy' on Amazon or iTunes (Lifehacker). Yes, You Can Own the Movies You Buy from Apple, Kinda (Gizmodo)

item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Memes and macros and GIFs…oh my
item.itunes:summary: Are memes an improvement on the way we express ourselves and communicate with other humans? MUSIC: “Universal Sound” - Tyler Childers ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: Highly Questionable - Papi Handshake Fake Out Compilation (YouTube)

item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A chat about commutes, the suburbs, and how our choices affect others
item.itunes:summary: Max moved for work, and that means he has a new commute. That sparks a conversation about commutes, how moving out to the suburbs affects other people, and a new way to think about the elusive concept of work-life balance. MUSIC: “I Can’t Do Without You” - Clarence Carter

item.title: Ep. 137: Opening Up "The Suitcase"
item.description: Digging into the most iconic episode of one of the most iconic shows ever
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Digging into the most iconic episode of one of the most iconic shows ever
item.itunes:summary: Pierce joins Sean in Charlottesville this week to talk about "The Suitcase," the episode of Mad Men (Pierce's favorite TV show) chosen at No. 2 in The Ringer's list of the 100 best television episodes of the 21st century. They talk about the parallels between the Don-Peggy relationship and the iconic Liston-Clay fight that features prominently in the episode, whether Don is the worst manager ever, and of course, the iconic line: "That's what the money's for!" MUSIC: "Nervous Young Inhumans" - Car Seat Headrest

item.title: Ep. 136: The Lost Episode
item.description: This day was bound to come sooner or later
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: This day was bound to come sooner or later
item.itunes:summary: Well, we blew it. The third time may be the charm, but my granddaddy always taught me is that the 136th time is the one where things go haywire on you. We had some technical issues that forced us to scrap this week's pod, but we'll see you right back here next week.

item.title: Ep. 135: Is Restaurant Week Maybe Bad?
item.description: Could reduced restaurant prices actually not be a good thing for eaters?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Could reduced restaurant prices actually not be a good thing for eaters?
item.itunes:summary: Another year, another Restaurant Week. Restaurants roll out fixed-price menus that give eaters a taste of their offering at a reduced price. Seems like a great idea, right? So...why does Sean hate it so much? We're delving into the difference between price and value, how the atmosphere in a restaurant changes during Restaurant Weeks, and the beauty of appreciating luxury and picking your spots. MUSIC: "Organ Donor" - DJ Shadow

item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK

How did he first get into the genre? What should new converts listen to? And what the fuck is...crabcore? MUSIC: "Whiskey in the Jar" - Metallica

item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Thoughts on a (dying?) service that always seemed too good to be true
item.itunes:summary: Oh snap, Max is back! He joins Pierce and Sean for a discussion of MoviePass, which certainly appeared to be failing last week (NOTE: Since we recorded this, MoviePass announced changes to the service which would limit users to three movies per month in exchange for keeping the price at $9.95 per month and removing certain restrictions on what movies/showtimes are eligible). How has it changed moviegoing in 2018? And what will we do if it goes away? MUSIC: "Heat Wave" - Snail Mail

item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK

item.itunes:summary: Pierce and Sean have a very involved conversation about sandwiches. What makes a sandwich great? Why are tomato sandwiches so good? And what are their favorite sandwiches? MUSIC: "Fire" - Special Explosion

This week, he and Sean are talking about oral histories. Why are they so effective as a storytelling device? And why don't we see more of them? MUSIC "Midway" - Bad Bad Hats ADDITIONAL MATERIAL Meet Me in the Bathroom Is the First Great History of New York’s 21st Century Rock Scene (SPIN) Blue Chips:An oral history of Shaq, Penny, and the Orlando Magic’s lost NBA dynasty (Grantland) The Greatest Paper That Ever Died (Grantland)

item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK

item.itunes:summary: This week, an experience Pierce had with someone taking pictures of their food for the 'gram sparked a conversation about photography at concerts, rules to live by, and the importance of being good to your fellow humans. Sean closes the show by raving about the movie he saw on the 4th and lamenting how we don't make them like we used to (role models, not movies). MUSIC: "Here's Your Future" - The Thermals

item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK

LeBron is a Laker! They talk about the move, the other dominos that might fall next, and what LeBron's legacy in L.A. will be. Oh, and they indulge in a little Kobe hatred. Or maybe a lot. Let's just say that Kobe Bryant will not be appearing as a guest any time soon. MUSIC: "Basketball" - Kurtis Blow

item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Graduations and birthdays and weddings, oh my!

Are there times when it makes more sense to not give a thoughtful gift that demonstrates how much you value a friendship? And why are we still committed to wedding registries instead of "first apartment registries?" MUSIC: "Mixer" - Nap Eyes ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: The economic case against Christmas presents (Vox)

item.itunes:subtitle: A discussion of some of the things that people are insufferable about

He and Sean talked about why, and spent a few minutes celebrating the life of Anthony Bourdain. MUSIC "Not Losing Sleep" - Thin Lips ADDITIONAL MATERIAL Anthony Bourdain Was Remarkable Because He Possessed Qualities That Shouldn’t Be (The Root) How to Live, According to Anthony Bourdain (Munchies)

There's not that much that's actually similar about Michael Jordan and LeBron James: different positions, different styles of play, different body types, different rules enforced by the referees, you get the picture. So why is everyone so hung up on which one of them is the G.O.A.T.? And is there a better way for us to celebrate transcendent athletes? Now that it's up to the states to decide, Sean and Pierce talk about sports betting and their visions of what a legalized, regulated gambling industry might look like. Could the gang see themselves working in a WeWork space instead of, say, working at a coffee shop? And what level of lunacy would be required for them to dive into WeLive, which applies the same ethos to...your apartment? MUSIC: "How Simple" - Hop Along

It sparked a bit of an argument, so Kevin joined the pod for a discussion about dessert in restaurants and whether they should be addressed with the same creativity as the rest of the menu. As always, Pierce apologizes. And Sean and Kevin talk about increasingly absurd sub-genres of heavy metal. MUSIC: "Ice Cream Man" - Raekwon

They talk about why they love the show so much and why it's so hard to compare it to any other show on TV. As always, Pierce apologizes. And Sean closes out the show with some words about local radio—specifically, the WTJU Rock Marathon. item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK

item.itunes:summary: It's less than a week into baseball season, and we already have a high-profile dustup over the "unwritten rules" of the game. The guys discuss the lunacy of having such an extensive parallel code of etiquette in a sport that has black-and-white, zero-sum outcomes and a well-defined set of actual rules pertaining to gameplay, and why it's different from the social contract we abide by in our everyday lives. Then, Pierce apologizes for how he comes across, and Sean shouts out a great new album. MUSIC: "Follow Your Arrow" - Kacey Musgraves

With an assist from Kevin, the group therapy session turns into a discussion of underdogs, how expectations change when your team wins, and whether or not Jim Boeheim is actually good now that he's come to Tony Bennett's defense. As always, Pierce apologizes for something, and Sean shouts out print newspapers (yes, this is still 2018). MUSIC: "The Underdog" - Spoon

item.description: A chat about a sporting event under-appreciated by the people on this podcast
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: A chat about a sporting event under-appreciated by the people on this podcast
item.itunes:summary: This week, Sean and Pierce have a confession: They haven't really been paying attention to the Winter Olympics. They talk to noted winter sports fan Max about how the Summer and Winter Olympics are interesting in very different ways and how the Olympics aren't even the pinnacle of most of their sports. As always, Pierce apologizes, and Sean shouts out a movie (spoiler: it's Black Panther, which is really, really good) and a book. MUSIC: "DEVASTATED" - Joey Bada$$ ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: How NBC Flubbed Its Coverage, Reported The Wrong Gold Medalist, Then Botched The Correction Of One Of The Most Stunning Upsets In Olympic History (Deadspin)

item.title: Ep. 108: Satisfaction Guaranteed...?
item.description: The iconic brand is making a change. Why is it happening, and is it perhaps a good thing?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: The iconic brand is making a change. Why is it happening, and is it perhaps a good thing?
item.itunes:summary: This week, the guys talk about the end of an era: the era of L.L. Bean's famously generous return policy, which is finally coming to an end...or is it? Also featured in this episode: inter-species justice, someone who should have caught these hands, and a positive change from a company looking to help people make positive changes. MUSIC: "BOOGIE" - BROCKHAMPTON. ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: South African lions eat 'poacher', leaving just his head (BBC) / L.L. Bean Has Ended Unlimited Returns, and I Am Fairly Certain It’s My Fault (Slate) / Weight Watchers scraps its before-and-after photos because diets are forever (The Takeout)

item.title: Ep. 107: Goodbye, CDs?
item.description: Best Buy is taking CDs off its shelf. Target may follow suit. How did we get here?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Best Buy is taking CDs off its shelf. Target may follow suit. How did we get here?
item.itunes:summary: The guys are talking about Best Buy's recent decision that it will take CDs off the shelves. What will take their place? And does this mean the compact disc is dying? As always, Pierce apologizes for something. And this week, Sean shouts out some movies he's seen recently. MUSIC: "Love, Like Language" - Happy Abandon ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: Best Buy to Stop Selling CDs (Pitchfork). Does Vinyl Really Sound Better? (Pitchfork). RIAA Sales Data, 1973-2016

item.title: Ep. 106: Cheap Eats
item.description: Max ate Vegemite. Will he ever be the same?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Max ate Vegemite. Will he ever be the same?
item.itunes:summary: A conversation about Max's experience with Vegemite in Australia leads to a discussion of inexpensive regional foods. Why did a restaurant in Mississippi start serving pig-ear sandwiches? What happens when "the food of the people" gets co-opted by hipsters and rich people? And what are hot dogs really made of? (Just kidding--we don't actually want to know either.) MUSIC: "Night Shift" - Lucy Dacus

item.title: Ep. 105: Let's Get Fantastical
item.description: Why are fantasy and sci-fi series so appealing?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Why are fantasy and sci-fi series so appealing?

item.title: Ep. 104: Your Google Home Isn't Spying On You...Yet
item.description: Virtual assistants are taking over. What do you need to know?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: Virtual assistants are taking over. What do you need to know?
item.itunes:summary: This week, Max is back from his jaunt around the world, and the gang is talking about virtual assistants. They discuss the Internet of Things, unknown unknowns, and why your biggest concern right now is not that someone will hack your Amazon Echo and take over your home. Then Pierce checks in with a trademark apology and offers up a fascinating scientific update. MUSIC: "The Embers" - Vagabon. ADDITIONAL MATERIAL: Don't Buy Anyone An Echo (Gizmodo)

item.title: Ep. 103: Rockstars
item.description: What does the term mean, and who are the rockstars of today?
item.itunes:author: It's Pretty OK
item.itunes:subtitle: What does the term mean, and who are the rockstars of today?
